indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.# of officials from Government Ministries, Agencies, and Regional Councils trained on Result-based management, medium term expenditure framework, monitoring and evaluation. 2. Integrated Result-based management and monitoring and evaluation system for NDP3 in place.

baseline.comment: 1. No Integrated Result-based Management and Monitoring and Evaluation system for NDP 3 in place.

target.comment: Improve the capacity of National Planning Commission on data analysis and reporting through the NIMD and Poverty Mapping Support the development of the baseline data on the root causes of poverty resulting in the production of the Namibian Index of Multiple Deprivations (NIMD) and Namibia Poverty Mapping . Support the National Planning Commission (NPC) to develop a web based data base on government policies that will enable O/M/As to successfully evaluate the effectiveness of intra-governmental policies on socio economic development in order to ensure progressive planning, coordination and implementation of sectoral policies and programmes. Support the operationalization of the coordination of the Poverty Cluster in line with National Gender Policy and its Plan of Action. Support NPC with the training on T21-Namibia Model for government planners that was developed in collaboration with the Ministry of Environment and Tourism (MET) during 2011-2012.

actual.comment: Baseline data on the root causes of poverty resulting in the production of the Namibian Index of Multiple Deprivations (NIMD) and Namibia Poverty Mapping developed and finalized. NIMD and Poverty mapping reports finalized and distributed to all 14 Regions and adopted as the official statistics A web based data base on government policies that will enable O/M/As to successfully evaluate the effectiveness of intra-governmental policies on socio economic development in order to ensure progressive planning, coordination and implementation of sectoral policies and programmes developed and finalized. Meetings for operationalization of the coordination of the Poverty Cluster in line with National Gender Policy and its Plan of Action undertaken and AWP developed. Training on T21-Namibia Model for government planners that was developed in collaboration with the Ministry of Environment and Tourism (MET) during 2011-2012 undertaken.

target.comment: Improve the capacity of National Planning Commission on data analysis and reporting through the NIMD and Poverty Mapping Support NPC with the generation of the baseline data on the root causes of poverty in the country, which resulted in the development of the Namibian Index of Multiple Deprivations (NIMD) and Namibia Poverty Mapping reports. Support NPC to development the capacity of National Development Advisors in the area of poverty and social impact analysis. This support directly contributed to the achievement of NDP4. Training of National Development Advisors to establish policy researchers. Support the newly formed Ministry of Poverty Eradication and Social Welfare to develop the National White Paper on Wealth Redistribution and Poverty Eradication Support GRN to develop the Final 2015 National Millennium Development Goals progress report.

actual.comment: The generation of the baseline data on the root causes of poverty in the country improved through the development of the Namibian Index of Multiple Deprivations (NIMD) and Namibia Poverty Mapping reports. Capacity of NPC National Development Advisors in the area of poverty and social impact analysis developed and strengthened through training provided by the Stellenbosch University . UNDP supported the newly formed Ministry of Poverty Eradication and Social Welfare to develop the National White Paper on Wealth Redistribution and Poverty Eradication. The regional dialogues in all 14 regions on status of poverty undertaken. The National Conference on Wealth Redistribution and Poverty Eradication undertaken. Report is available. Final 2015 National Millennium Development Goals progress report developed and finalized.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: National Gender Policy and its National Plan of Action developed National GBV Plan of Action developed Capacity of MGECW Staff enhanced National Coordination Mechanism established and approved by Cabinet Gender Responsive Budget directives in place and capacity of all O/M/A developed Male Engagement Action Plan developed

baseline.comment: 1. 16% of successful prosecution of rape and domestic violence cases 2. 1997 National Gender Policy and 1998 to 2003 Plan of Action 3. 2000 to 2005 number of rape cases were at 39% 4. Gender Based Violence database not reflecting all required gender variables 5. No Coordination Mechanism exist 6. Male Engagement initiatives in Namibia non-existent

target.comment: Systematic Gender Responsive Budgeting system/guidelines developed for the Ministry of Finance and other Line Ministries National Planning Commission GRB Training Manual reviewed and finalized # of non-traditional organization and stakeholder especially men on GBV engaging the fight against GBV Research on the reasons behind passion killing and the cost of GBV on Namibia's Economy conducted and concluded by 2015 National Coordination Mechanism established and approved by cabinet National Coordination Mechanism and different cluster implemented in all 14 regions

actual.comment: Cabinet Directives - Budget Circular to all O/M/As to engender their budgets and sector execution plans Ministry Of Finance compelling all Line Ministries to prepare and submit gender responsive budgets by 2015 Male engagement initiative implemented, partnership established with the Namibia National Premier League and the Bus and Taxi Association Research study by UNAM on the GBV with a specific focus on the cost of GBV on the Namibian Economy undertaken, draft in place to be finalized in 2015

target.comment: Implementation all components of CM at all levels especially the GAC to provide for the much needed political support GRB Training Manuals and Guidelines to be finalized, printed and distributed Training of Trainers on Gender Responsive Budgeting to be undertaken All GBV Campaign materialize to be reviewed and developed for the implementation of comprehensive GBV Zero Tolerance Campaign Male Engagement activities to be intensified Standard operating procedures and protocols for GBV developed

actual.comment:
In 2015, the MGECW supported by United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) commissioned analyses of the respective budgets and MTEF proposals in 2015 for seven Ministries namely Ministry of Education, Arts and Culture; Ministry of Defense; Ministry of Health and Social Services; Ministry of Safety and Security; Ministry of Works and Transport; Ministry Higher Education, Training and Innovation and Ministry of Finance, which collectively are allocated about 70% of the total expenditure budget to assess progress in the implementation of the Cabinet Directive on GRB. The findings of the analyses introduces strategies for addressing challenges in GRB and map out a strategy of on how to strengthen GRB in Namibia. The assessment was followed by a TOT Workshop for the assessed ministries to enable them further strengthen GRB practice in the respective institutions. The TOT workshop attracted 32 participants, consisting of 22 women and 10 men, of the participants, 3 are part of the pioneer group of the Master of Arts in Gender Studies Course at the University of Namibia which was establish through funds and technical assistance of UNDP who were specially invited to take part and provide their expert advice.
Through a MOU between civil societies in responding to the strategic interventions in the National GBV Plan of Action to engage men in key male dominated sectors in the prevention of gender based violence the Football Fraternity was selected as a focus group this year. 18 Football players from the 8 of top teams in the Namibian Premier League where trained and guidelines materials have been developed for them. The key result is to introduce, increase and strengthen the involvement of the soccer fraternities in efforts aimed at addressing Gender Based Violence . Banners were developed with messages of GBV and will be used as awareness raising tools during all Premier League Football matches.
In 2013/2014 the Multidisciplinary Research Centre and the United Nations De

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Five (5) Landscape Conservation Areas (LCA) in place and fully functional/operational by 2014

baseline.comment: Landscape management remains uncoordinated and biodiversity is lost over time. Current METT scores as follows: ML (71) GWL (69), GSNL (37), GFRCL (46), WGB (30): average: 51.

target.comment: 1. Develop framework and guidelines for the implementation of the National Policy on Protected Areas' Neighbours and Resident Communities and support the inclusion of Landscape Conservation Concept into the Protected Areas and Wildlife Management Bill. 2. Develop through consultative process best practices on landscape conservation areas establishment. 3. Consultative process to develop the sustainability and replication plans 4. Utilizing the business opportunities identified in SEA and business planning process, research appropriate supply chains either under certification or based on ecologically sustainable market growth opportunities; and Supply chain models developed and selected that identify potential BEE opportunities through diversification/ value addition. 5. Finalize and adopt biodiversity indicators at landscape level for improved monitoring and Integrate the biodiversity indicators into the tourism venture certification system

actual.comment: 1. On-going. Five-year Strategic Management plans have been developed and approved by respective landscape committees for Mudumu, Greater Sossusvlei-Namib, Greater Fish River and Windhoek Green Belt Landscapes while a draft Strategic Management Plan was developed for Greater Waterberg Landscapes. All approved Strategic Management plans were published and distributed to stakeholders. The plan for Windhoek Green Belt Landscape was further translated into German for easier reference by stakeholders. 2. On-going. The Ministry of Environment and Tourism with project support is developing Implementation Guidelines for the National Policy on Protected Areas Neighbours and Resident Communities. This Policy is the first legislative framework in the country that recognizes the formation and promotion of landscapes Conservation Areas. The policy also forms the foundation for inclusion of Landscape Conservation Areas into the Protected Areas and Wildlife Management Act under development.The development of these Implementation Guidelines are necessary as the Ministry of Environment and Tourism recognizes that some of the initiatives such as deriving benefits from protected, establishment of Landscape Conservation Areas and creation of wildlife corridors and dispersal routes are less understood, complex and sensitive. To ensure that these initiatives are correctly managed, it is important to establish guidelines. These Implementation Guidelines will provide role players and stakeholders with comprehensive information on the processes and important aspects to consider. Equally, the development of Implementation Guidelines are critical to the project as the process will also review various collaborative initiatives in the country; capture best practices and lessons learned from these collaborative arrangements; and identify potential collaborative initiatives to be explored for replication. 3. The Project Steering committee approved the sustainability and replication plans with th

target.comment: 1) Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created 2) METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level 3) Framework for collaborative management among stakeholders within landscapes / targeted 5 LCAs in place by year 5. 4) National level best practices guidelines for the establishment of new LCAs in place by April 2015 5) 5 LCAs with constitutions in place for 5 landscapes 6) Infrastructure is in place for all LCAs based on assessment by December 2015 7) Partnership Committee for each LCA in place by year 5.

actual.comment: 1) There is strong evidence that wild animals are increasingly using corridors created within Landscapes Conservation Areas. Various Landscape Conservation Areas have shown varying degrees on corridor usage. Research on wildlife movement using satellite collars on key species in Mudumu Landscape have shown the usage of corridors with the landscape and wildlife dispersal between Botswana, Namibia, Angola and Zambia. Similar trend has emerged in the Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscape Conservation Area where preliminary results from the research on wildlife movement have shown fences obstructing wildlife movement and unobstructed movement where fences have been removed or are poorly maintained. In Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape Conservation Area, the annual game census carried out on the Gondwana Private Nature Reserve within the landscape has shown fluctuating population numbers of Mountain Zebra compared to previous annual censuses suggesting that they are moving within the /Ai-/Ais Hot Springs Game Park and adjacent land particularly where fences were removed or poorly maintained due to the rugged terrain. To fully understand the wildlife populations in Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape, the Ministry of Environment and Tourism with support from the project undertook a landscape-level aerial survey for the Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape to understand the population dynamics of the landscapes. The consultants are analyzing the results with the final report expected by March 2016. This large and increasingly open Landscape is currently poorly understood in terms of wildlife numbers, movements and distribution. The effects of climatic variation are poorly understood as are the dynamics between vegetation and wildlife. To better understand these parameters, comprising an aerial survey of the landscape to determine wildlife numbers for all ungulate species, and the use of camera traps, set in strategic clusters, to determine specifically Mountain Zebra movemen

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National level best practice guidelines in place for the establishment of LCAs

baseline.comment: Draft MET Protected Area management planning policy guideline in place

target.comment:
National level best practice guidelines for the establishment of new landscapes in place by April 2015
(The target on National level best practices guidelines for the establishment of new LCAs in place by year 5 was changed to National level best practices guidelines for the establishment of new LCAs in place by April 2015.
MTR recommendation - This indicator is suitable; we recommend changing the target date to April 2015 as the LCAs have been established and the guidelines can now be written and approved)
PSC - The timeframe was endorsed as recommended

actual.comment: The Project is developing lessons learned, challenges and best practices in the establishment of landscape conservation areas in Namibia. To ensure objectiveness of the process, the project contracted a consultant to develop these practices. Furthermore, the project is arranging to host a National Workshop to Share the experience. In addition to the development of these lessons learned, challenges and best practices, the project has show cased the project at various global stages that include the IUCN World Parks Congress in Sydney, Australia and the World Bank Annual Conference on Land and Policy in Washington DC, USA.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Constitutions in place for 5 landscapes.
(The indicator and target on Partnership agreements in place for 5 landscapes; Constitutions in place for 5 landscapes was changed to Constitutions in place for 5 landscapes and 5 LCAs with constitutions in place for 5 landscapes respectively); MTR recommendations - This indicator has been achieved but the terminology should be changed, as appropriate, to remain consistent, with clear definitions (e.g., partnership agreements vs. constitutions)

baseline.comment: Constitutions in place for conservancies and drafts for GWC, GSNC and GFRCC.

target.comment: 5 landscapes with approved constitutions in place by year 5

actual.comment: Partially acheived. The projet has revised Landscape Conservation Area constitutions following the decision by the Ministry of Environment and Tourism management not to sign the constitutions pending the finalization of the Protected Areas and Wildlife Management Bill. Based on the Implementation Guidelines for the National Policy on Protected Areas Neighbours and Resident Communities, constitutions will be signed by landscape stakeholders or the Landscape Conservation Area Association excluding the Ministry of Environment and Tourism. Once the consititutions are signed, the association will enter into a Memorandum of Unerstanding with the Ministry of Environment and Tourism for the management of the respective protected areas and adjacent land as a single landscape conservation area

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Landscape threats and sustainable land uses defined (setting the scene to develop regulations, standards and codes of practice); Regulations, standards and codes of practice developed for each landscape; National level best practice codes of practice in place.
(The indicator and target on Landscape threats and sustainable land uses defined (setting the scene to develop regulations, standards and codes of practice); Standards and codes of practice developed for each LCA; National level best practice codes of practice in place was split into the following indictors and targets: Indicator - Standards and codes of practice developed for each Landscape Conservation Area and Target - Standards and codes of practice developed for each LCA by Dec 2014; and Indicator - National level best practice codes of practice in place and Target National level best practice codes of practice in place by Dec 2015) MTR recommendations - There are four components each with a different output to this indicator:
i) identification of the threats at a landscape level (already done at PPG stage)
ii) defining sustainable land uses in each LCA (already done to some extent at PPG stage but this should be included in the LCA management plans)
iii) developing standards and codes for each LCA (these have been done to some extent already but guidelines and regulations for each LCA building on the constitutions and management plans still need to be done) and
iv) Publishing the best practice codes at a national level.
Thus, the first two are not relevant (as they were done in the PPG stage).
We recommend that the standards and codes (akin to guidelines and regulations) are developed for each LCA with a target date of Dec 2014; those in the GW LCA will be developed later (once the issues in this area are sorted out).
Standards and codes at a national level should then be finalised by Dec 2015.

baseline.comment:
Biodiversity threats defined for all landscapes
- Land use zoning maps suggesting suitable land uses at conservancy, park and complex level
- Draft PWMB in place and draft constitutions for GFRCC, GSNC and GWC
- Park specific regulations in place (which parks?)
- Guiding principles in park M+D plans and conservancy management plans

target.comment: Landscape threats and sustainable land uses defined by year 5; landscape level regulations, standards and codes of practice for biodiversity conservation in place by year 5; National level codes of practice, based on best practice, in place by year 5.

actual.comment: Partially acheived. The development of code of practice to be done upon completion of the development of the National Level Best Practices.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Infrastructure, based on approved recommended priorities, are in place for 5 landscapes.

baseline.comment:
Mudumu - fire management equipment, water points; GWC - guard posts, boundary fences, fire management equipment, water points; WGB - park and farm fences, water points, guard post at DVJ; GSNC - fences, water points, guard post; GFRCC - fences, water points, guard posts, solid waste management and Radio communication at (/Ai-/Ais).
(Updated in 2013 at Project Steering Committee based on needs assessment)

target.comment:
All infrastructure is in place for all landscapes based on assessment by December 2015
(The target on Infrastructure is in place for all LCAs based on assessment by year 5 was changed to Infrastructure is in place for all LCAs based on assessment by December 2015 MTR recommendations - This indicator is suitable; no suggested changes but to reiterate that the infrastructure should be relevant to the goal and objectives of the project. All infrastructure should be in place by Dec 2015

actual.comment: Partially achieved: In addition to the already developed infrastructure in various landscapes, the project developed further infrastructure such as the a) infrastructure supporting the Khomas Hochland Hiking Trail in Windhoek Green Belt Landscape Conservation Areas; and b) tourist game viewing hide at Santika Waterpoint in Mudumu Landscape Conservation Area. Other infrastructure development yet to be completed include the upgrading of the Sesriem Gate in Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscape to reduce dawn bottlenecks and office accommodation for the 4 Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area conservancies.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description:
Landscape Conservation Areas (LCAs) are established and ensure that land uses in areas adjacent to existing Protected Areas are compatible with biodiversity conservation objectives, and corridors are established to sustain the viability of wildlife populations (GEF 4.5 mill USD)
(This resolution was reached at inception meeting for landscape not to pursue protected areas status due to realities on the ground influenced by the land reform program in the country)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created
(The indicator and target on Trends in increased abundance and distribution of selected species was changed to Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created. MTR recommendation - What may be more important than the abundance estimates (which are unlikely to change significantly over the course of this project), are i) the changes in the movement patterns of animals particularly in those areas in which the fences have been removed (as may be measured through distance travelled by and/or home range sizes of collared animals using the data that is already being collected), and ii) changes (if any) in the use of corridors by animals (usually using data from collared animals).
Although the change was endorsed, the Project Steering Committee felt that due to the high costs associated with wildlife movement research using collars, the project is to use existing data.

baseline.comment:
Key species collared to monitor wildlife movement in Mudumu and Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscapes)
(Baseline changed from Abundance estimates for game in place at conservancy and park level. Mudumu Landscape (excluding Mamili): Buffalo 1 214; Giraffe - 205; Impala 6 795; Wildebeest 2 305 (Source September 2011 Dry Season Count, MET, NACSO); Greater Sossusvlei Landscape: Naukluft Mountains part of the Namib Naukluft Park: Mountain Zebras 2 600 (Source June 2013 Aerial Survey, MET); Greater Waterberg Landscape: Waterberg Plateau Park: Buffalo 550; Roan Antelope 180; Sable Antelope 100 (Source September 2012 helicopter survey, MET); Windhoek Green Belt Landscape: Daan Viljoen Game Park: Oryx 150; Zebras 180 (Source MET estimates only)to Key species collared to monitor wildlife movement in Mudumu and Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscapes)
PSC - The change was endorsed. However, the Committee felt that due to the high costs associated with wildlife movement research using collars, the project is to use existing data.

target.comment: Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created

actual.comment: Partially achieved: There is strong evidence that wild animals are inreasingly using corridors created within Landscapes Conservation Areas. Various Landscape Conservation Areas have shown varrying degrees on corridor usage. Research on wildlife movement using sattelite collars on key species in Mudumu Landscape have shown the usage of corridors with the landscape and wildlife dispersal between Botswana, Namibia, Angola and Zambia. Similar trend has energed in the Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscape Conservation Area where preliminary results from the research on wildlife movement have shown fences obstructing wildlife movement and unobstructed movement where fences have been removed or are poorly maintained. In Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape Conservation Area, the annual game census carried out on the Gondwana Private Nature Reserve within the landscape has shown fluctuating population numbers of Mountain Zebra compared to previous annual censuses suggesting that they are moving within the /Ai-/Ais Hot Springs Game Park and adjacent land particularly where fences were removed or poorly maintained due to the rugged terrain.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 5 landscapes are established to improve biodiversity conservation at landscape level; an additional 15,550 km2 brought under collaborative management with protected areas

baseline.comment: 4 existing landscape conservation partnerships in place

target.comment: 5 landscapes established by year 5 with at least 15,550 km2 additional land under collaborative management with protected areas, being ML (1,469), GWL (7,500), GSNL (173), GFRCL (5,750), WGB (658)

actual.comment: Achieved during the reporting period of 2012. The area protected by the established LCAs of 35,049km significantly exceeds the targeted 15,550km

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level
(The indicator and target on Improved systems level operations capacity has ensured a reduced level of threats to habitats and species composition; Landscapes maintain global biodiversity values; METT scores are improved in protected areas within landscapes was changed to METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\")
MTR Recommendation - We propose that this indicator is reduced to one that focuses exclusively on the METT scores both at the landscape level (i.e., for each LCA) but also within each of the state-managed protected areas (i.e., there should be a METT score for each LCA and for the state-managed PA in each area).
The aspects of species diversity should be removed it has not been monitored to date, there is no baseline and anyway the project is unlikely to influence species diversity over its lifetime (except, perhaps, an agreement to remove all exotic species from the LCAs).

baseline.comment: Landscape management remains uncoordinated and biodiversity is lost over time. Current METT scores as follows: ML (71) GWL (69), GSNL (37), GFRCL (46), WGB (30): average: 51

target.comment: METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level

actual.comment: The METT assessment is planned for second half of 2015. The METT assessment carried out in 2013 for the MTR showed an increase by 12 in the average score across the five landscapes.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Framework in place for collaborative management among stakeholders within landscapes.

baseline.comment: Draft MET Protected Area management planning policy guideline in place

target.comment: Framework for collaborative management among stakeholders within landscapes/ targeted 5 landscapes in place by year 5.

actual.comment: Partially achieved: The National Policy on Protected Areas Neighbours and Resident Communities was approved by Cabinet and officially launched. It became the legislation in Namibia that recognizes landscapes Conservation Areas. Further to the policy, The MET with project support developed Implementation Guidelines for the effective implementation of the policy. The policy will pave way for inclusion of landscape conservation into the Protected Areas and Wildlife Management Bill being developed with support from the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Key short, medium and long-term development issues identified and disseminated; StrategicManagement plans, based on the key issues for each area, in place for 5 landscapes defining management objectives, standards, rules and procedures for landscape functions.

baseline.comment:
Management and development plans for parks (AHGP, NNNP, BMM and Waterberg?)
- Draft parks and Wildlife Management Bill (PWMB) and Regulations
- Draft PA Management planning policy guideline in place
- Environmental Management Act, Draft Regulations and guidelines in place to guide development planning
- National CBNRM Framework in place
- parks and Neighbours and Concessions policies in place
- Draft Protected Area Association of Namibia (PAN) constitution in place (with agreed affiliation by GRFCC , GSNC1 and GWC1)
- Draft constitutions in place for GFRCC, GSNC, GWC and MNC. Mudumu south conservancies have constitutions.

target.comment: Strategic Management plans for each landscape in place by December 2015

actual.comment: Partially achieved: Four of the five Landscape Conservation Areas have approved Strategic Management Plans. Only the Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area is yet to have its draft plan approved by the Landscape Management Committee.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
Management and development plans in place for interested landscapes partners (e.g. conservancy, private farm, PA).
(Revised in 2013 at Project Steering Committee after partners felt that only interested partners should have management plans)

baseline.comment:
Management and development plans for parks (AHGP, NNNP, BMM and Waterberg?)
- Draft parks and Wildlife Management Bill (PWMB) and Regulations
- Draft PA Management planning policy guideline in place
- Environmental Management Act, Draft Regulations and guidelines in place to guide development planning
- National CBNRM Framework in place
- parks and Neighbours and Concessions policies in place
- Draft Protected Area Association of Namibia (PAN) constitution in place (with agreed affiliation by GRFCC , GSNC1 and GWC1)
- Draft constitutions in place for GFRCC, GSNC, GWC and MNC. Mudumu south conservancies have constitutions.

target.comment: Management and development plans are in place for interested landscapes partners by year 5.

actual.comment: Partially achieved: All protected areas within the five landscapes have approved management and tourism development plans. Although all parks have plans, Naute Recreation Resort, Daan Viljoen Game Park and Waterberg Plateau Park are yet to be approved by the Minister.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description:
Landscape management and development plans in place for all 5 landscapes.
This Indicator was incorporated into the Strategic Management Plan Indicator
MTR recommendation - The amended version of this indicator (strategic management plans) is suitable; no suggested changes.
The Strategic Management Plans are complete for GFRCL, GSNL and Mudumu (notably the three areas with greatest capacity). The Strategic Management Plans for the GWL and WGBL should be completed by Dec 2015 at the latest.

baseline.comment:
Management and development plans for parks (AHGP, NNNP, BMM and Waterberg?)
- Draft parks and Wildlife Management Bill (PWMB) and Regulations
- Draft PA Management planning policy guideline in place
- Environmental Management Act, Draft Regulations and guidelines in place to guide development planning
- National CBNRM Framework in place
- parks and Neighbours and Concessions policies in place
- Draft Protected Area Association of Namibia (PAN) constitution in place (with agreed affiliation by GRFCC , GSNC1 and GWC1)
- Draft constitutions in place for GFRCC, GSNC, GWC and MNC. Mudumu south conservancies have constitutions.

target.comment: Management and development plans are in place for each Landscape by year 5.

actual.comment: : Partially achieved: Four of the five Landscape Conservation Areas have approved Strategic Management Plans. Only the Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area is yet to have its draft plan approved by the Landscape Management Committee.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Partnership roles and responsibilities defined and agreed and Partnership Committees in place for each landscape.

baseline.comment:
Management committees in place at conservancy and complex level and Park Wardens appointed by MET
- Roles and responsibilities of Management committees defined in Management and development plans and in the job descriptions of Park Wardens

target.comment: Partnership Committee for each landscape in place by year 5.

actual.comment: Achieved. All Landscape Management Committees established in 2012 are still operational.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Key development issues defined for the SEA (drawing earlier consultation work); SEA in place with recommendations for tourism development in each landscape.

target.comment: SEA of the tourism sector completed for the 5 landscapes.

actual.comment: Achieved: All five Landscape Conservation Areas Strategic Environmental Assessments of the Tourism Sector for all five Landscape Conservation Areas were developed and adopted by respective landscapes.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Business plans in place for major initiatives supported in landscapes based on SEA recommendations and drawing other existing work.
(Revised in 2013 at Project Steering Committee as Business plans at landscapes level was seen as not practical as protected areas are not managed on business principles. Furthermore, private sector partners felt that sharing business plans would compromise individual businesses due to rife competition in the sector)

baseline.comment: Business plans in place for Ai-Ais Hot Springs Game Park and Bwabwata-Mamili-Mudumu (BMM) National Parks; Business and sustainbility plans in place for conservancies in Mudumu North Complex (MNC).

target.comment: Business plans for major initiatives in 5 landscapes in place by year 5

actual.comment: On-going. The Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area with support from the project is developing Income Generating Options for landscape as a mean to sustain its activities due to limited revenue generation opportunities.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Biodiversity monitoring and assessment system developed for each landscape and recommended at national level for integration into a national tourism venture certification system

baseline.comment:
SPAN Biodiversity indicators (being developed at present)
- National CBNRM Programme biodiversity indicators published in the State of Conservancy Report (SoCR)
- ICEMA biodiversity indicators that would be adopted by MET (for long-term M&E)
- NBSAP in place with biodiversity management objectives national level
- Local level monitoring (LLM) systems in place at conservancy level; incident (monitoring) books in place for parks.
- CPP integrated sustainable land management indicators and Land Degradation Monitoring System (LDMS) with biodiversity indicators.

target.comment: Biodiversity monitoring indicators in place by year 5 for each landscape and across landscapes.

actual.comment: Partially Achieved: Different landscapes are at different stages of developing monitoring systems. Mudumu Landscape has a well-developed integrated system within protected areas and conservancies that uses the Incident and Event Book Monitoring systems. The Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Namib has developed a Game Count Data Management System for an Integrated Monitoring System for the stakeholders. The first Integrated Landscape Game Count was undertaken across all properties on 20 June 2015. Similarly, the Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape is mirroring efforts from the Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscape.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Supply chains developed based on current and potential markets for the diversification of current goods and services and/ or the development of new ones; Supply chains identified for certification; Markets established and mobilised for certified supply chains.

baseline.comment:
Cheetah-friendly beef initiative that could be used for lessons learnt and best practices
- Current biodiversity-friendly off-take/ harvesting practices by private tourism operators/ game farmers (potentially not documented); Research by ICEMA on indigenous natural products.

target.comment: Supply chains defined and markets explored/ established for new/ diversified goods and services.

actual.comment: On-going. The project has supported the diversification of current goods and services within landscapes. These include: a) Enhancing the Klein Karas Community resilience to effects of climate change through a community Garden; b) Production of tourist products by Women Sewing Project of Klein Karas Community in Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape; and c) Diversifying livelihood among stakeholders in Windhoek Green Belt Landscape through development of Khomas Hochland Hiking Trail; and d) Development of new tourism route in Mudumu Landscape Conservation Area.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Key operational aspects defined for each landscape; Agreement in place for cost and benefit sharing for each landscape.
Indicator was removed
MTR Recommendation - This indicator should be nested within the strategic management plans that are being produced for each LCA (see Output 2.1 above). Indicator should be removed.
PSC - Indicator to be removed as it is nested within the strategic management plans that are produced for each LCA

baseline.comment: Current cost sharing arrangement in place at NamibRand Nature Reserve (NRNR); Cost sharing modalities in place in Mudumu between government, private sector and communities.

target.comment: Cost sharing agreements for each landscape in place by year 5.

baseline.comment: No AC strategy in place No HR strategy in place

target.comment: 1. Human rights framework drafted and finalized. 2. National AC strategy finalized. 3. Engage civil society for increased participation of women and youth in elections.

actual.comment: 1. Human rights framework drafted and finalized. 2. National AC strategy finalized. 3. Engage civil society for increased participation of women and youth in elections.

target.comment: Institutional capacity of the Anti-Corruption Commission to investigate, prevent and to educate the public on corruption has been strengthened and developed. Development and implementation of National Human Rights Action Plan Development and implementation of plans for 5 of the 7 strategic areas based on the Human Rights Action Plan Development and printing of a Compendium of Human Rights Law for Parliamentarians Enhancement of capacity of the newly elected Members of Parliament on Human Rights treaties and obligations is

actual.comment: The Institutional capacity of the Anti-Corruption Commission to investigate, prevent and to educate the public on corruption has been strengthened through the development of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy and Action Plan. Furthermore there is evidence of an increase in the number of the cases referred to the Prosecutor General, from 45 in 2011/12 to 55 in 2012/13. Namibia has progressed to be in compliance with the United Nations Convention against Corruption. National Human Rights Action Plan developed and implemented. Plans for 5 of the 7 strategic areas based on the Human Rights Action Plan developed and implemented A Compendium of Human Rights Law for Parliamentarians compiled and printed. The capacity of the newly elected Members of Parliament was enhanced through training provided on human rights treaties and obligations.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Barriers to CSOs effectiveness to facilitate community participation in SLM in the context of the UNCCD Ten Year Strategy removed.
At least 8 position papers on topical issues published by CBOs/CSOs/NGOs/ community groups and presented in at least 5 side events and or International meetings/conferences/conventions/platforms.
Local grassroots organizations in Sub-Saharan Africa empowered to participate and influence the implementation of the UNCCD, TerrAfrica and other SLM processes, programmes and policies.

baseline.comment: Very few SSA members of the CSO community attend the UNCCD events and pre-event preparation is haphazard and non-effective

target.comment: 1. Complete studies on the Social and environmental accountability in the extractive industry in western Africa. 2. Preparation of a documentary on commercial land grabs preceded by literature review. 3. Develop, Launch, Organize the Equator Initiative Prize event for SLM in SSA. 4.Develop 5 functional thematic areas (Agriculture, Agro-forestry, renewable energy, Gender and SLM, Conservation and Management of natural resources) for coordination with 5 thematic area leaders in place 5. Environmental Capacity building training for journalists 6.Develop and finalize a communication strategy for the project

actual.comment: 1.OSISA has completed its consultations with its sister company OSIWA (Open Society Initiative for West Africa) to undertake the study. A road map is also designed indicating the milestones and the respective timelines for their completions. 2. Literature review on the impacts of commercial land grabs in sub Saharan Africa has been commenced and the draft report is completed. The main issues findings in the review include characteristics of land deals, target countries, types of land investment, trends and drivers, impacts of land grabs, analysis of land grabs in the context of sustainable land management, laws and regulations governing reporting foreign land deals. Specific countries in sub Saharan Africa have been identified for case studies and review. A discussion was also held on collaboration with the Institute for Poverty, Land and Agrarian Studies (PLAAS). Themes for collaboration already identified entails developing documentary on land and agriculture commercialization as well as land governance, food security and climate change. 3. Equator Prize for Sustainable Land Management (SLM) in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) call for nominations was launched January on 22nd and closed March 22nd 2014. Outreach materials on the SLM prize were created in English, French, Portuguese, Arabic and Swahili, and distributed to all project partners and relevant networks in the region. Preparations have begun for the Award Ceremony which is scheduled for June 17th 2014 in Nairobi, Kenya. 4. Selection of thematic leaders was launched and 15 applicants have expressed interest. Second appeal for applications has been made to prospective applicants particularly in Anglophone organisations and those from Southern Africa. Selection criteria for the thematic leaders have also been developed. 5. This activity is scheduled for second quarter (June, 2014). 6. TORs for communication, advocacy and branding strategy consultancy have been finalized and the procurement process is put in

1) Over 40 community members representing groups from different countries in Sub Saharan Africa attended UNCCD COP11 in Namibia in 2013 courtesy to the project. During the conference, Equator Initiative organized 8 side events on SLM, as part of the World Indigenous Network (WIN) Dialogues. These side events included: Sustainable Use of Water in Sub Saharan Africa; Women Empowerment in Sustainable Land Management; Community-Based Natural Resource Management; Knowledge Exchange for Capacity Building and a session on the Post-2015 Agenda. Most of these side events were driven by community representatives, participating in panel discussions. The dialogues were an opportunity for peer-to-peer knowledge exchange among local communities and indigenous groups, as well as an opportunity for them to interact with policy makers, government representatives and officials of the UNCCD. 2) 21 journalists from southern Africa, East and West Africa attended this training workshop which was facilitated by experts from University of Cape Town; Science Africa, Kenya; UNCCD Secretariat, OSISA, ENDA and other partners. Participants were equipped with skills for investigative journalism in the environment and human rights field. They were exposed to emerging issues in land management and different knowledge platforms where access reference materials and documents to support their stories on sustainable land management. As a result, the training workshop contributed to increasing the pool of international journalists who can write regularly Sustainable Land Management and raise public awareness. 3) The consult for the final evaluation is currently on board. The inception report outlining the methodology and work plan. The evaluation report will be ready by end February

result.title: Objective:
result.description: To empower local grassroots organizations in SSA to participate in and influence the implementation of UNCCD, TerrAfrica and other SLM processes, programs and policies

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of SLM friendly policies influenced
at local, national or regional levels as a result of CSO and community advocacy

baseline.comment: Civil society in some countries are engaged in advocacy but there is no baseline of policy change due to this advocacy due to lack of monitoring processes

target.comment:
At least 4 countries modifying policies on land as it relates to resource governance and long-term leasing as a result of CSO contribution through advocacy ;
At least 4 countries engage in open, widely consultative national debate on impacts of land grabs and biofuels on national heritage and food security as a result of CSO contribution in advocacy.

actual.comment: Africa conference on land grabs was held on 28th and 29th October, 2014 Midrand, South Africa. Result-Continental working group on land grabs constituting members from South Africa, Senegal, Zimbabwe, Kenya and Tanzania was established

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of communities (or members) adopting best practices learnt from the SLM innovation competitions and documentation

baseline.comment: The Equator initiative is facilitating competitions for innovative initiatives and disseminating lessons learnt, but these do not focus on SLM/LD specifically. There is therefore limited information on a baseline of adoption influenced by the outcomes of such competitions.

target.comment: This indicator is shared between the CSO and other SIP host projects. At least 10 land managers and/or farmers from the winning initiatives replicate it following publication of the prizes and lessons

actual.comment: Following the successful Equator Prize for SLM held in Kenya, 4 awardees of the prize have held in country celebrations. The celebrations have been supported by UNDP country offices and have been platforms for exchange of ideas and urging other community members to adopt the best practices. The policy makers invited to the in country functions have also been able to see what works and this is one of the initial steps in influencing policy on sustainable land management. Cases in point are Burkina Faso, Benin, Swaziland and Ghana where these in country celebrations took place.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increased capacity of the CSO community in SSA to advocate emerging SLM issues to regional, national, and sub-national institutions

baseline.comment: There is no documented Baseline on the capacity of CSOs to advocate on emerging SLM issues

target.comment:
By project closure, an advocacy strategy on imparting change to regional, national, and sub-national policies on natural resource governance is prepared and agreed upon by the PSC and the board of the CSO coordination mechanism.
By project closure, a memorandum of understanding is agreed upon with TerrAfrica for recognizing the planned CSO coordination mechanism as their CSO representative partner.

actual.comment:
A draft advocacy strategy on imparting change to regional, national and sub national policies on natural resources governance has been prepared but yet to be ratified by the PSC and the board of the coordination mechanism. The draft is attached for review as the process for finalization is on-going.
Secondly, with regard to agreement on memorandum of understanding between the project board and the TerrAfrica on the recognition of the planned CSO mechanism as CSO representative in TerrAfrica, communication is on between the project management unit, PSC members and TerrAfrica and the memorandum will be signed in October during TerrAfrica Board meeting in Ankara, Turkey at the COP12.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Increased resources flowing to SLM from diverse sources

baseline.comment: At the design of the project, there had been an earlier attempt by RIOD as an organization that was working on dryland issues in Sub Saharan Africa. RIOD was evaluated to be a weak institution that had no program of work and the resources to drive the agenda of the institution forward.

target.comment: By project closure, a strategy is formulated that outlines a sustainable program for recognizing innovation in community-level SLM in SSA; including roles and responsibilities, an operating budget, financing sources, and an outline of managing the process on the website of the CSO coordination mechanism.

actual.comment: The establishment of the coordination mechanism is on course. The mechanism for the CSOs has already been registered in Senegal as Africa Coalition for Sustainable Land Management and draft programme of work developed. A critical stakeholder consultation was held by the end of March 2015 which brainstormed on the strategic objectives and pertinent activities for the institution. The consultations took place during the PSC meeting and the coordination mechanism workshop.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Coordination of African CSOs improved to enhance partnerships for effective coordination and knowledge transfer:

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Change in the number of SSA CSO attending UNCCD COPs and CRICs

baseline.comment:
Very few SSA members of the CSO attend the UNCCD events and pre-event preparation is haphazard and non-effective. At COP10 held in the Republic of Korea,
From the UNCCD website, I found that the following 5 CSOs from SSA participated in the COP 10, the following CSOs from Sub Saharan Africa attended:
1. ENDA Tiers Monde, Senegal; 2. ICLEI, Local Governments for Sustainability, South Africa; 3. Friends of the Earth, Ghana; 4. Association Prudence au Saher, Burkina Faso; 5. Association for Combating Desertification, Ethiopia

target.comment:
At least 35% increase in numbers attending and improvement in pre-event preparations
By project closure, the CSO coordination mechanism develops and agrees to a strategy on facilitating rotational opportunities for CSOs in each of the three regions to participate in international and regional SLM events.

actual.comment:
Even though there was marked improvement (over 100%) increase in the attendance of CSOs at the last COP11 in Namibia, there is a challenge in sustaining the momentum of the number of people attending continuously. For instance, COP12 which is to be held in Ankara, Turkey, the project is targeting and preparing to take at least 12 members of different communities that won the Equator Prize for SLM. Funding for the participation of prospective CSOs members is being mobilized. It worth noting that the target of 12 well over the 35% target given at the design of the project but the overall challenge for the project is for the coordination mechanism to take the facilitation of CSOs to attend the subsequent COPs as one of its responsibilities.
In regards to developing a strategy on facilitating rotational opportunities for CSOs in each of the three regions of sub Saharan Africa to participate in international and regional SLM events, this is part of overall Coordination mechanism strategic plan which is currently being developed. The strategy is among other things focusing on sustaining the flagship activities initiated by the project like attending COPs and other international SLM events.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Effectiveness of CSO preparation for and participation in UNCCD COPs and CRICs and other international fora

baseline.comment: With the exception of the Drynet members, SSA CSO body pre-event preparation is chaotic, there is minimal collaboration between CSO groups outside the UNCCD events

target.comment: At least 50% increase in pre-event preparedness and quality of participation, indicated by number of discussions held on important topical subjects and positions reached and delivered at the UNCCD events

actual.comment:
UNCCD Conference of Parties (COP12) is planned to take place in October 2015 in Ankara, Turkey. In order to improve the preparation for attending the COP, ENDA as Africa Regional Representative in the UNCCD CSO Panel and the implementing partner for outcome II of the project was involved is involved in the planning process. Critical milestones achieved in this regard include:
o Consultation of African CSOs for contributions to the CST4 and the CRIC 13 through email exchange
o Information sharing with more than 50 CSOs through the mailing list about international fora (DesertifAction Forum-Montpellier (France) June 2015; Social Forum, Tunis, March 2015, all these events have been attended by representatives of the CSOs and discussed the upcoming COP12)
o CST4 and CRIC 13 reports and updates shared as part of the build up to participation at the COP12
o A CSO workshop has been planned for September 2015 with one of the Agenda being preparation of the CSOs for the COP

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Extent to which the CSO coordination mechanism is functional, has a program of work and resources

baseline.comment: Currently RIOD is not functional; it has no office, no program of work and no funds. Regional network of representatives have no incentives to implement a RIOD program of work and the network exists only in name

target.comment: A vision for SLM amongst CSO developed; coordination mechanism registered (is a legal entity in a selected country), program of work and funds raised, a constitution agreed and other modes of operations understood, shared and agreed

actual.comment:
The progress made since July 2014 towards the establishment of the functional coordination mechanism include:
1. Sub regional thematic leaders appointed in East, West Central and Southern Africa
2. Registration of the coordination mechanism as a legal entity in Senegal
3. Program of work developed for the coordination mechanism following brainstorming and presentations by the respective thematic leaders
4. Fundraising proposal has been drafted and presented for consideration to Human Rights Initiative within the Open Society Foundations.
The outstanding work to be finalized within the remaining time is the formulation of strategic plan including the resource mobilization component for the mechanism.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Community Innovation in SLM recognized, rewarded and upscaled

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of SLM innovation competitions organized and awards issued

baseline.comment: The equator initiative currently organizes competitions and gives prizes for communities along the equator, based on innovative biodiversity conservation initiatives that contribute to livelihoods and reduce poverty. Although these have often included initiatives that support SLM, they have not been targeted at the implementation of the UNCCD specifically.

target.comment:
At least 30 Community groups (CBO/CSOs/ NGOs, farmers/herders associations etc.) participate in at least 5 international and regional UNCCD, TerrAfrica, CAADP and other conferences and contribute to debate on policy issues (community dialogue spaces);
Local leaders from at least 30 CBOs/CSOs/NGOs and other community groups trained to promote advocacy initiatives

actual.comment:
Progress made since July 2014 include a number of milestones as indicated below:
o An Equator Prize Ceremony hosted in New York, on 22 September 2014, for the three finalist SLM winners in which three winners of the Equator Prize for SLM participated in the recognition of best practices at the Global event
o The community dialogues were held at UNDP headquarters in New York City prior to (and after) the Equator Prize ceremony, on 18th, 19th, 20th, and 23rd September 2014; these dialogues were attended by the three winners of the Equator Prize for SLM which had been hosted in June 2014, Nairobi. The dialogue sessions included workshops on grant writing, social marketing and elevator speeches as well as other thematic sessions on fellowships.
o The Equator Initiative represented by the WIN (World Network of Local and Indigenous Land and Sea Managers) participated in the IUCN World Parks Congress 2014 held in Sydney, Australia, from 12 November to 19 November 2014. At least three community group members from the sub Saharan Africa region participated at the event which among other issues discussed the impact of extractive industry on the communities' livelihoods and conservation areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number and quality of award winning case studies published and disseminated

baseline.comment: Several award winning cases published from the Equator initiative and the UNDP organized Farmer Innovation, but none of them have been specifically targeted on LD/SLM issues

target.comment: At least 5 publications released and disseminated documenting best practices

actual.comment: As at June 2015, an additional publication on the SLM winners 2014 booklet had been done. The booklet gives the profiles of the 12 winners and showcasing the best practices and the contribution that they have made in their communities in the arena of SLM and poverty reduction. A detailed and in depth publication of the same 12 winners is on course and will be finalized in August 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number and quality of community dialogues held at national level following CSO/community dialogues at the international fora

baseline.comment: Currently local dialogue being organized for the Equator Initiative price winners but this is not targeted at LD/SLM constituencies

target.comment: At least 15 local level dialogue facilitated by returning communities/ CBOs who attend the international dialogue as potential price winners

actual.comment: Four in-country dialogues have been carried out by the returnees. The dialogues have been organized by the winners of the Equator Prize for SLM and have been hosted in collaboration with UNDP country offices. The in country dialogues have also involved the participation of policy makers and other key stakeholders in the project. These dialogues have taken place in Swaziland, Ghana, Burkina Faso and Benin

result.title: Outcome1
result.description: CSO Technical Capacity in SLM and knowledge based advocacy increased

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of current and emerging areas in which CSO produce knowledge based recommendations and advocacy material

baseline.comment: Drynet hosts regular side events with at least one policy paper at each UNCCD event. However, Drynet membership is limited, does not comprehensively cover SSA

target.comment: At least 8 position papers on topical issues published by CBOs/CSOs/NGOs/ community groups and presented in at least 5 side events (in conjunction with outcome 1). Topics will link effects of policies on SLM practice and poverty reduction e.g. trade, land tenure, governance, carbon finance, etc.;

actual.comment:
1- Six country reports (Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania in East Africa and Niger, Ghana and Guinea-Conakry in West Africa) on Social and environmental accountability studies on the extractive industry have been completed. Also finalized are two regional policy briefs synthesizing the findings from east and west African studies on social and environmental accountability in the extractive industry.
2. At the Eastern and Southern Africa CSO, Coordination workshop, 8th -10th October- Dar es salaam, the CSOs took position on GMOs, Natural resource management, mainstreaming of gender in SLM and effective information sharing.
3. In August 2013, the project through ENDA hosted a regional CSOs meeting that took position with regard to the impact of desertification and land degradation leading to food insecurity and loss of income resulting in conflicts. The declaration called for mitigation of land degradation and coordination of CSOs efforts.
4. In June 2014, Equator Prize winners for SLM made a declaration on their commitment to sustainable development, restoring graded lands, conserving their ecosystems for present and future generations and calling on African governments to enhance protection of natural resources.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of CSO receiving training in relevant SLM, CC and NRM subjects

baseline.comment: Currently there are many organizations offering training on topical SLM/LD, CC and NRM subjects, but the training is often expensive and not specifically focused on SSA level issues. Many CSO groups are resource poor and cannot afford to self-sponsor for training

target.comment:
At least 4 training courses developed on topical subjects and at least 4 training workshops organized that reach at least 100 CSO groups (with interest). The training made available on line and in hard copies; partnership with an LD/SLM institution facilitated to sustain training
By project closure, a training delivery and development strategy is developed and agreed by the PSC and board of the CSO coordination mechanism.

actual.comment: A draft training delivery and development strategy has been formulated and is to be presented to PSC members for further review before final presentation to the Coordination Mechanism Board.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of functional partnerships formed with research institutions

baseline.comment: TBD

target.comment: At least five partnerships formed with the project

actual.comment:
The focus of developing partnership has changed over the last 3 months. This has been re-oriented towards science and technology institutions for the purpose of helping in the building of capacities of CSOs and enhancing the sustainability of the work under outcome 1 for increasing CSO technical capacity for SLM facilitation and knowledge based policy based advocacy. Through secondary literature review and consultation with various development partners, seven science, technology and research institutions have identified and initial consultations have been initiated. These institutions include:
a) African Centre for Technology Studies based in Nairobi Kenya
b) Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) based in Nairobi Kenya
c) Forum for Agricultural Research in Africa (FARA) based in Accra, Ghana
d) Regional Universities Forum for Capacity Building in Agriculture (RUFORUM) based in Kampala, Uganda
e) African Network for Agriculture, Agroforestry and Natural Resources Education based in Nairobi, Kenya
f) UNDP Dryland Development Centre based UNEP Campus, Nairobi Kenya
g) Technical Centre for Agricultural Rural Cooperation (CTA) based at Wageningen University of Agriculture in the Netherlands
It is estimated that by October, partnerships with at least half of them will have been formalized through signing of MOUs between the Coordination Mechanism Board and the respective institutions.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 50 MW CSP Solar Power Plant set up by 2017/18

baseline.comment: No single CSP Solar Power Plant in Namibia.

target.comment: 1. Inception workshop to be held 2. Establishment of the PMU and MOA between MME and NAMPOWER for Feasibility Study and EIA 3. CSP planning and implementation mechanisms established within MME 4. Enhanced knowledge of applicable CSP applications in Namibia

actual.comment: 1) The Inception Workshop was held in April 2014, with a project start stated at the workshop to be May 1, 2014. 2. The MoA between MME and NamPower was signed in March 2015, officially involving NamPower in the project, and introducing an updated timeline for the implementation of outcomes. The MoA based its timeline on that of the inception report Establishment of the PMU and MOA between MME and NAMPOWER for Feasibility Study and EIA 3. CSP planning and implementation mechanisms established within MME PMU (NPM & EH) conducted scoping and final selection field visit to Kunene and Oshikoto region during 20-22 June & 17-19 July 2015. This is in view of selecting 2GM future site to reach project target in addition to the 3 sites to be done by Nampower. The 2 additional sites to be done by NEI with the 2nd successful technical Nampower tender with Geo Sun 1. Etanga. 2. Opuwo (Kunene) 3. Onashikakoya (Oshikoto) With final selection visit with GeoSun, the final selected sites will be Etanga & Oshikoto. The 2 additional sites are also strategically selected to offer GM stations more spread across the country towards completion of Namibia solar map and also to consider CSP heat application. During the field visit NMP managed to get approval with site owners for Oshikoto site which will be set up at Uris guest lodge for the Etanga site, this site belongs to the Traditional Authority. . 4. Ongoing, the Project have contracted a team on consultants for capacity building advice. the consultants started conducting the needs capacity needs assessments on 17 Jul 2015 to advise on the to advise Enhanced knowledge of applicable CSP applications in Namibia

target.comment: 1) Local entrepreneurs are engaged in the manufacturing, supply and installation of CSP systems 2) Increased investments in CSP technology applications in Namibia 3) Increased installed capacity of CSP plants in Namibia

actual.comment: 2) Ongoing; site selection of 5 target solar ground measurement sites were finalised. The contracts of contractor to install ground measurement stations at 3 were finalised. The draft Renewable Energy Policy incorporating CSP was formulated. The draft IPP Framework Guidelines was obtained1) Ongoing; The CSP capacity building workshop for 40 entrepreneurs, engineers, policy-makers and academia was conducted. Knowlege-sharing and technology transfer partnership with SolarPaces and Ministry of Mines and Energy was finalised. The CSP Interest Database for linking local and international stakeholders is in place with 50 and 30 entries; The project is currently drafting the partnership Agreement Templates. 10 local entrepreneurs were engaged in enhancing capacity and interest in expanding into manufacuring, financing and the provision of CSP linked services. 3) Ongoing; the draft Implementation Agreements Framework was formulated. The draft EIA for one of the 5 ground measurement sites available and being refined for CSP plant criteria.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To increase the share of renewable energies in the Namibian energy mix by developing the necessary technological framework and conditions for the successful transfer and deployment of CSP technology for on-grid power generation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Cumulative direct post-project CO2 emission reduction resulting from the investment in CSP by end-of-project (EoP), Mtonnes CO2.
% share of CSP in the power generation mix of Namibia by EoP

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Cumulative direct post-project CO2 emission reduction resulting from the investment in CSP by end-of-project (EoP), Mtonnes CO2.
% share of CSP in the power generation mix of Namibia by EoP
NB: Revision of Indicator targets - As per the findings of the Mid-Term Review, these indicators were over-ambitious and cannot be achieved during the project timeframe. Indeed, it is logically impossible to expect a project to achieve post-project emission reductions by the end of the project. The indicators were not sufficiently amended to reflect the project redesign requested by GEFSec during the protracted project preparation phase. Specifically, the indicators do not accurately reflect the revised goal of the project, which is to have the feasibility study for a CSP plant in place by the end of the project, not to construct the plant itself.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
BUR1 endorsed and submitted to the UNFCCC 2014
GHG inventory data for key sources collected GHG inventory team trained and fully functional Data measurement and analysis is institutionalized Complete inventory chapter is prepared for the FBUR

baseline.comment:
Initial work on the GHG Inventory initiated under the Namibia's Third National Communication (NC3).
INC & SNC have been submitted in 2002 and 2011 respectively and TNC under implementation.

target.comment:
BUR1 endorsed and submitted to the UNFCCC 2014, with the following elements:
GHG inventory data for key sources collected GHG inventory team trained and fully functional Data measurement and analysis is institutionalized Complete inventory chapter is prepared for the FBUR
BUR with the above may result in its approval.

actual.comment:
The Namibia Bienial Update report was finalised and submitted to the in UNFCCC in Lima on 3 December 2014. This resulted in Namibia being rated as the first developing country to submit its mitigation measures report.
The report, called biennial update report (BUR) provided a summary of Namibias actions to implement the Convention, including actions taken to mitigate climate change, as well as their effects. It also included information on greenhouse gas emissions. Additionally, the report spelled out financial, technological and capacity-building needs and support received.

target.comment: BUR 2 developed and submitted to UNFCCC for approval in 2015.

actual.comment: The BUR 2 project was approved by the UNFCCC and the GEF in June 2015. The BUR 2 is currently under implementation.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Implementation of the Integrated Fire Management Strategy

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 8. Number of hectares under improved integrated fire management

baseline.comment: SOPs are currently not in place

target.comment: 100% of Namibias PAs (135,906 ha)

actual.comment:
National Fire Management Strategy developed and approved.
ToR for development of SOP for each PA finalized.
Improved Fire Management practices, Namely: (a) Introduction of Early Burning to minimize biomas / fire load as a strategy to counter adverse fire impacts during the fire season, (b) maintenance of fire-breaks and (c) creation of new fire breaks - where necessary, to contain, limit and confine fire outbreaks to smaller areas / burned patches at a time. For the reporting period, these activities were predominantly implemented in Etosha (2,227,000 ha), Khaudum (384,000 ha) and Bwabwata (610,000 ha) = (3,221,000 ha in total.
